repnme.cdata!:
India - Andhra Pradesh Cyclone Emergency
            Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Andhra Pradesh
            Cyclone Emergency Reconstruction Project for India was
            satisfactory. The project achieved its major objectives, its
            impact on institutional development has been substantial,
            sustainability is uncertain at this time, and the
            performance of both the Bank and Borrower was satisfactory.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First,
            project design should be fully responsive to government
            expectations and people's needs by giving priority to
            actions which ensure quick restoration of economic activity
            and benefit the largest number of affected people. Second,
            if certain technical studies are considered crucial to
            provide updated plans, then special covenants in the
            credit/loan documents should be included to stipulate a
            timetable for such things as the preparation of TOR and
            recruitment of consultants. Third, project procurement
            procedures comprising LCB and post-qualification for a large
            number of small contracts minimizes the delays usually
            associated with ICB procurement of larger packages. Fourth,
            the establishment of an effective PMU in the Ministry of
            Finance enhances project performance and the probability of
            success. Fifth, the establishment of separate
            project-dedicated wings in the main implementing agencies
            ensures that project activities are given special attention
            and kept detached from the routine departmental activities.
            Finally, firm Borrower's commitment provides a sound
            foundation for efficient project implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Andhra Pradesh Cyclone Emergency
            Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Andhra Pradesh Cyclone Emergency
            Reconstruction Project consists of the following urgent
            reconstruction activities: (a) reconstruction and
            rehabilitation of irrigation and drainage systems in the
            delta areas; (b) reconstruction and repairs to roads and
            bridges, with particular attention for stabilizing slopes
            and repairing roads in hilly tribal areas; (c) construction
            of additional cyclone shelters; (d) repairing and
            strengthening electricity transmission systems, hospitals,
            water supplies, telephone exchanges and administrative
            centers; (e) rehabilitation of horticultural crops,
            facilities for inland fisheries and damaged ports; (f)
            construction of headworks for rural water distribution to
            villages most vulnerable to flood induced contamination; (g)
            reconstruction of municipal roads, drains and water
            supplied; (h) reconstruction of public buildings including
            elementary and primary schools and medical buildings; (i)
            construction of coastal shelter belts; (j) housing; and (k)
            technical assistance to finance technical studies to develop
            a plan to modernize water management in the delta and upland
            river areas; provide consultant services; training and
            equipment for the disaster awareness program; and to
            introduce non-governmental organizations in support of
            tribal development initiatives and in the fishing communities.
